But existing range data for this taxon must now be regarded as unreliable, since they are based almost exclusively on specimens collected as adults that were determined prior to description of M.myrmicae. The only populations of Microdon mutabilis sensu Sch√∂nrogge et al (2002a, b) studied by those authors were from Britain and Ireland. The presence of the species has subsequently been confirmed in Sweden (Bartsch et al, 2009b). Beuker (2004) and Reemer et al (2009) no longer regard M.mutabilis as present in the Netherlands. Bonelli et al (2011) were unable to confirm the presence of M.mutabilis sensu Sch√∂nrogge et al (2002a, b) from anywhere in central Europe, where its known host ant, Formica lemani is largely subalpine, implying that M.mutabilis would be likewise subalpine there. However, it has since been established (Van de Meutter, 2015) that a lowland, dry grassland ant species, F. cunicularia, can act as host for M. mutabilis larvae. By contrast, M.myrmicae occurs in wetlands in the montane zone and at lower altitudes in central Europe. On this basis, the adults of M.mutabilis that can be found in well-drained subalpine grassland in Switzerland presumably belong to M.mutabilis sensu Sch√∂nrogge et al (2002a, b), highlighting the need for better information about the high-altitude populations of M.mutabilis in the Alps.

Similarly, the use of the systemic pesticides, the Ivermectins, in cattle, appears to be causing a decrease in the frequency of R.campestris at present, though there is as yet no experimental work on the degree of toxicity of these chemicals to Rhingia larvae - Ivermectins excreted in cow-dung are known to be lethal to dung beetles (Aphodiidae etc.).
